docs.lead_paragraph: A jury in California yesterday awarded $116 million in punitive damages to a patient's widow who contends he died after a subsidiary of Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, delayed approving treatment for stomach cancer that its own doctors had recommended. Lawyers on both sides called it the largest such verdict against a health maintenance organization. Aetna said it was confident that the damages would be overturned on appeal, as would a finding by the jury in San Bernardino County Superior Court last week awarding $4.5 million in actual damages in the 1995 death of David Goodrich, 44, a career local prosecutor.
docs.abstract: Jury in San Bernardino County, Calif, Superior Court awards $116 million in punitive damages to David Goodrich's widow, Teresa, who contends her husband died after subsidiary of Aetna Inc, nation's largest health insurer, delayed approving treatment for stomach cancer that its own doctors had recommended; lawyers on both sides call it largest such verdict against health maintenance organization; Aetna says it is confident that damages will be overturned on appeal, as will finding by jury, which awarded $4.5 million in actual damages in 1995 death (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a breakthrough in one of New York City's largest unionization drives in decades, the machinists' union has signed a contract on behalf of nearly 700 drivers at one of the city's largest black-car companies, Elite Limousine Plus. With the union seeking to organize the city's more than 12,000 black-car drivers, labor experts said the agreement with Elite could pave the way for most of the city's 41 other black-car companies to sign union contracts.
docs.abstract: International Assn of Machinists signs contract on behalf of nearly 700 drivers at one of New York City's largest black-car companies, Elite Limousine Plus; labor experts say that agreement with Elite could pave way for most of city's 41 other black-car companies to sign union contracts; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health needs to develop a broader strategy for finding out why poor people and some ethnic minorities are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive them than is the rest of the population, an expert panel said today. The institutes, the Federal agency that sponsors most of the nation's medical research, needs to expand the study of why ethnic and racial groups are disproportionately affected by cancer and make certain that minority groups are adequately represented in research trials, the panel said in a report.

headline.main: Study Urged On Cancer And Races

docs.abstract: Expert panel convened by Institute of Medicine urges National Institutes of Health to develop broader strategy for studying why poor people and some ethnic minorities are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive them than rest of population; urges Institutes to assure that minorities are adequately represented in research trials; recommends discarding tradition racial categories and studying people on basis of their ethnic and economic backgrounds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an almost, but not quite, unanimous display of support, Democratic members of Congress rallied around President Clinton this evening, invoking nearly identical phrases as they applauded Mr. Clinton's proposals and urged an end to the partisan warfare that has threatened his Presidency. Aware of Mr Clinton's history of delivering State of the Union speeches that stretched past newspapers' night deadlines, Democratic leaders were faxing out their reactions even before he finished speaking and were reaching through history for superlatives to praise his performance.

headline.main: Swift and Strong Support for the President, Though Some Slip Fold
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: THE DEMOCRATS

docs.abstract: Most Democrats in Congress rally round Pres Clinton's State of the Union speech, applauding his proposals and urging end to partisan warfare that threatens his Presidency; a few, including Sens Paul Wellstone and Ernest F Hollings, attack his policy proposals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The bull market in stocks, running hard for more than eight years now, has already lived longer than any other in history. And if President Clinton gets his way, the gallop will continue. The President's plan to shore up Social Security calls for putting $700 billion into the stock market. His idea is to transfer almost two-thirds of the projected Federal budget surplus, roughly $2.7 trillion, to the Social Security trust fund over the next 15 years and funnel $700 billion of that into stocks.

headline.main: Wall Street Not Exactly Bullish On Plan to Aid Social Security
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: THE MARKETS

docs.abstract: Investors react tepidly to Pres Clinton's proposal to invest $700 billion of new Social Security funds in stocks over 15 years, move that would boost stock prices; plan, which raises questions about Government's role in market, is likely to face stiff opposition (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After surveying the body of scientific literature on lesbian health and holding workshops with researchers and clinicians, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine issued a report last week deploring the gaps in reliable information about lesbian health. The panel called for large-scale studies to counter rampant ''myths and misconceptions'' and to improve the quality of treatment lesbians are receiving. ''In the face of little empirical information, there are numerous beliefs and misconceptions about the health risks of lesbians that can affect their health outcome,'' said the report, called ''Lesbian Health: Current Assessment and Directions for the Future.''

headline.main: Fact, Fiction and the Health of Lesbians

docs.abstract: Panel of experts convened by Institute of Health issues report deploring gaps in reliable information about lesbian health (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will embrace an idea long favored by conservatives and propose a tax break for parents who stay home to care for their children, White House officials said today. The proposed tax credit, up to $250 a year for each child under age 1, is smaller than the tax breaks proposed by Republicans for the same purpose. But the Administration now accepts the Republican argument that the Government should recognize the value of services provided by a parent, generally the mother, who forgoes paid employment to stay home and care for the children.

headline.main: Clinton to Propose Tax Break For Parents Who Stay at Home

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will embrace idea long favored by conservatives and propose tax break for parents who stay home to care for their children; Administration now accepts Republican argument that Govt should recognize value of services provided by parent, even though tax credit of up to $250 per year for each child under one year old is smaller than tax breaks proposed by Republicans for same purpose; will also give employers tax credit of $500 per year for each family that joins purchasing coalition to obtain health insurance and $200 for each person covered as individual (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Defiant Yugoslav Leader Orders U.S. Envoy Expelled Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader, defied the allies and threatened a fragile cease-fire when he ordered the expulsion of a top American diplomat, William Walker, after Mr. Walker blamed the Serbs for the killing of more than 40 ethnic Albanians in Kosovo last week. After the expulsion order, Serbian forces refused entry to a United Nations war crimes prosecutor who arrived at the border to investigate the killings. A1 Serbian forces pounded the hills surrounding the village where the ethnic Albanians were killed, ignoring NATO demands for an end to the onslaught. Fighting also spread to northern Kosovo, where five police officers were wounded. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Sungard Data Systems Inc., a computer service and software company, agreed to buy the FDP Corporation, which makes software for the insurance and pension businesses, for about $95.3 million in stock. Sungard, based in Wayne, Pa., sells its products and services primarily to financial institutions and health-care information services. The company said it wanted to buy FDP, based in Miami, to expand into its field. FDP will operate as a separate company within Sungard. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of March.

headline.main: SUNGARD DATA SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY FDP WITH STOCK

docs.abstract: Sungard Data Systems will acquire FDP Corp for about $95.3 million in stock (S)
